results.intro: We had intended to get a full day of packing ...
results.title: Moving Hours

message.body:
We had intended to get a full day of packing done yesterday, but we were traveling on Saturday and severe weather closed down the roads we needed to get home. We didn't get home until yesterday evening, and we only have today and tomorrow to pack because the movers arrive 9am Wednesday morning.

My plan is to work a half-day today and tomorrow, doing my work in the evening after a day of packing. I'll do a full day on Wednesday while the movers load up the trailer, and I'll do a half-day Thursday before we head back out on the road. We'll be splitting the drive up between Thursday and Friday, so I'll try to do a half-day after we get to Texas on Friday. I'll do a full day Saturday as well. If everything goes smoothly, I should still be able to get a full week of hours in. If things fall apart, then I'll catch up in the weeks that follow.

results.intro: We've gotten along well enough without one for a while. ...
results.title: Project Managers

message.body:
We've gotten along well enough without one for a while. Still, I've felt at times in the past that having someone officially in that capacity could have been beneficial. Having someone in that role can help with managing client expectations, organizing information transfer between the two parties, and identifying and resolving challenges earlier. I believe development can be a smoother process and more enjoyable when developers have a buffer from these activities. It can also add a unique dynamic to the client relationship that is sometimes hard to replicate when developers are trying to cover that role.

I haven't thought much through the logistics of (re-)establishing this role in our team. I'm willing to take on a role like this if it could work. I'm willing to be talked out of taking on a role like this.

latest_message.body:
I'm glad we're having this discussion, thank you for all the input.

After various replies and external chats it became clear that I probably didn't frame some ideas well initially. It looks like we're all in agreement that we can improve how we handle many aspects of the client communication channels. As well, we can optimize how we divvy up work that traditionally falls under the PM umbrella. My motivations are:

  1. We have a plan for improvement that is more explicit than saying "let's improve!"
  2. We streamline the how, who, and when aspects of managing coordination and communication; we don't leave these as secondary priorities.
  3. We better protect the maker blocks in our schedules while also reducing isolation. This includes things like reducing occasions where people are working relatively independently on a single feature for several days or more, yet ensuring that someone can take ownership of big features without worrying about (off-topic) interruptions.
  4. We continue to split in-project responsibilities as evenly as possible over the long term, without forcing people to work in roles they aren't comfortable with.

I feel like my concerns were heard, so thanks all.

results.intro: # Requirements: Following up with our discussion from yesterday Geordie, ...
results.title: GuestRetain Internal Communication

message.body:
Requirements:

Following up with our discussion from yesterday Geordie, let me summarize the requirements:

  • GuestRetain displays the user content in his language
    • We send out emails in his language (those are confirmation, sequences and survey response mails)
    • We display the survey form pages in his language

But languages do not need to be just "English" or "Spanish". A client also might want to send out two english emails.

We have the concept of groups already, ideally we re-use this to use them as a 'language like' switch.

A client could have groups

  • English
  • English VIP guests
  • Spanish

and he can send different emails and display a different survey form wording for each of this group.

Geordie, is that all correct and make sense? Are that all requirements you need for this context?

Implementation

So here was my idea from yesterday.

I am not sure if its still valid or required with the recent change (see my "Recent Change Problem" section below), I am not sure how to move forward.

  • We already have Groups for Guests, however they are pretty loosely coupled, they are optional for guests, a guest can be in many groups.

At first lets make the groups a ForeignKey. Every Guest can only be on one group. A group is required.

Every client will have at least one default Group. We name them "English".

  • Sequences, MailTemplates and SurveyData (the text we show along the survey form) will be different per Group. A client sets up Mailtemplates, Sequences and SurveyData for every single of his group.

This will allow him to send out different emails and show different texts for every single guest Group. They could be spanish, or different variations of english.

Thats pretty much it. I've thought about this in the past, thats why the SurveyData and ClientProfile is a One2One relation to the user and not attached to it. The database change will mainly be to add a "group" foreignkey for each of those models.

Recent Change Problem

Geordie and Chris,there is now this change where Kris added multi-lingual support for survey forms.

Seeing this I was a little bit concerned since thats not really what we discussed yesterday and I said that I'd like to talk to Kris first about this whole issue to bounce off ideas.

The change look like its either not finished or not thought-through. What we have now is:

  • As a spanish guest
  • I get a english welcome mail
  • I get a english email with the survey url
  • I click on survey url and see the survey written in spanish
  • I submit it and see a spanish string "Thank you"
  • I get a english email response

I also thought you said that confirmation templates are right now the most important thing (which makes sense to me).

Going forward, lets make things easy

So what can we do now? The change Kris made is not wrong at all, it just doesn't meet all your requirements.

To follow this route, what we can do next is, that we implement the above change (english, spanish extra fields) for the MailTemplates too. We will also add a field for each Guest indicating his language.

It will allow the client to send out english / spanish emails per guest.

Technically thats a easier change than what I proposed above but:

It will not allow the client to have different english emails for guest groups.

The guest groups are not used to organize guests per language.

Geordie if that works for you, we can proceed with that.

Geordie and Kris, if possible I'd like to move discussions around new features of GuestRetain to Ginger, and not in separate Skype chats where we don't know what the other is talking about and what the state is.

results.intro: # Efficient Sparkle Appcasts [XXX example image gingernotify left/right aligned ...
results.title: Blogpost (WIP) Efficient Sparkle Appcasts

message.body:
Efficient Sparkle Appcasts

[XXX example image gingernotify left/right aligned so the text flows around.]

Here at Lincoln Loop we wrote a small menu-based tool for our team discussion tool Ginger to indicate the arrival of new posts in the background. It's a MacOS tool and its currently in heavy development (and released ASAP). Heavy means here, that it gets an update almost every day.

With that, we needed a fast and efficient update mechanism within the app, something that checks every day for updates and installs it. On MacOS there are more-or-less two ways to deploy your app this way: You use the Mac App-Store with all its (dis)advantages or you use Sparkle. The latter is the de-facto standard if it comes to auto-updates and deployments on the user side. And so we integrated it.

How it works

Sparkle uses a RSS feed Appcast.xml with some custom sugar to check for new releases, each item is a release, each release has a separate sparkle:releaseNotesLink tag which points to a .html file with the latest Release Notes. Thats the description you'll see in the updater window, it's a simple Webkit canvas.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<rss version="2.0"
     xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"
     xmlns:sparkle="http://www.andymatuschak.org/xml-namespaces/sparkle">

    <channel>
        <title>GingerNotify Changelog</title>
        <link>https://path/to/Appcast.xml</link>
        <language>en</language>

        <item>
            <sparkle:releaseNotesLink>https://path/to/v2.4 (5) Release Notes.html</sparkle:releaseNotesLink>
            <pubDate>Mo, 10 Dez 2012 11:49:22 +0100</pubDate>
            <enclosure
                type="application/octet-stream"
                url="https://path/to/v2.4 (5).zip"
                sparkle:version="5"
                sparkle:shortVersionString="2.4"/>
        </item>

        <item>
            <sparkle:releaseNotesLink>https://path/to/v2.4 (4) Release Notes.html</sparkle:releaseNotesLink>
            <pubDate>Mo, 10 Dez 2012 11:49:22 +0100</pubDate>
            <enclosure
                type="application/octet-stream"
                url="https://path/to/v2.4 (4).zip"
                sparkle:version="4"
                sparkle:shortVersionString="2.4"/>
        </item>
    </channel>
</rss>

So, for every release there are quite a lot of actions to do:

  • Compile the app, sign, export and zip it
  • Create and write a new corresponding ReleaseNotes.html file
  • Add that to the "Appcast.xml" feed

And so you'll end up with a lot of files.

Make it simpler

The first thing you'll notice is that you don't really need a separate ReleaseNotes.html for every single release. They can all live in one file, one release after another. That has also the advantage that the user can see what happened in the past, not just in the very latest release:

Simpler!

Not bad, however there was one thing that bugs me most: Why do I have to write a ReleaseNotes.html file when I already have to update this Appcast.xml feed? We can totally do this in one file, the Appcast.xml holding both, the release list and its changes.

The idea is: First we add the release text, which would go into this separate file, into the feed. I added a new tag sparkle:releaseNotes for this, but if you want to keep it in-line with a classic RSS Feed, use `description'.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="Appcast.xsl"?>

// \…

<item>
    <sparkle:releaseNotes>
    <![CDATA[
        <ul>
            <li>Added a button to change Desktop notification settings right from the prefs screen</li>
            <li>Fixed the URL to obtain the API token</li>
        </ul>
    ]]>
    </sparkle:releaseNotes>
    <sparkle:releaseNotesLink>https://path/to/Appcast.xml</sparkle:releaseNotesLink>
    <pubDate>Mo, 10 Dez 2012 11:49:22 +0100</pubDate>
    <enclosure
        type="application/octet-stream"
        url="https://path/to/v2.4 (5).zip"
        sparkle:version="5"
        sparkle:shortVersionString="2.4"/>
</item>

The next step is to have the sparkle:releaseNotesLink point to itself:

<sparkle:releaseNotesLink>https://path/to/Appcast.xml</sparkle:releaseNotesLink>

What would happen now is, that the update window would display plain XML. Not very pretty. What we need is to transform that to some pretty HTML, and thats where an XSL Stylesheet comes into the game. 

<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="Appcast.xsl"?>

The webkit canvas supports XSLT (Version 1) so what will happen is: Sparkle uses the plain feed to obtain its information how to update the app. The webkit canvas loads this feed too, but because it supports XSLT, it will render the feed in a pretty style.

All you need to do is to place this Appcast.xsl along the .xml file:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

<xsl:stylesheet
    version="1.0"
    xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"
    xmlns:sparkle="http://www.andymatuschak.org/xml-namespaces/sparkle"
    xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">

<xsl:output method="html" encoding="utf-8" />

<xsl:template match="/">
    <html>
    <head>
        <title><xsl:value-of select="rss/channel/title"/></title>
    </head>
    <body>
        <xsl:apply-templates select="rss/channel/item"/>
    </body>
    </html>
</xsl:template>

<xsl:template match="rss/channel/item">
    <div class="release">
        <h1>
            <xsl:attribute name="title">
                <xsl:value-of select="pubDate"/>
            </xsl:attribute>
            <xsl:attribute name="id">
                <xsl:value-of select="enclosure/@sparkle:version"/>
            </xsl:attribute>
            Version <xsl:value-of select="enclosure/@sparkle:shortVersionString"/>
            (Build <xsl:value-of select="enclosure/@sparkle:version"/>)
        </h1>
        <xsl:value-of select="sparkle:releaseNotes" disable-output-escaping="yes"/>
    </div>
</xsl:template>
</xsl:stylesheet>

Done. There is visually no difference to before, but now there is only one file to maintain.

Even Simpler!

Lets add some sugar coat to this; I don't want to write HTML into my feed, most of the time there are some really plain strings for what was updated:

* Added feature A
* Fixed Bug B
* Fixed Bug C

Let's write this into the feed -- as is! 

<item>
    <sparkle:releaseNotes>
    <![CDATA[
        * Sparkle integration for easy updates
        * The app is now code-signed to work without warning on MacOS Lion and later
    ]]>
    </sparkle:releaseNotes>

    ...
</item>

We have to adjust the XSL a little to create list items out of those * starred lines . This is a really ugly syntax (in my opinion) but it does its job. XSLT2 has an internal function for this by the way, but neither Safari nor Chrome does support it yet. 

<div class="release">
    <h1>...</h1>
    <ul>
        <xsl:call-template name="textline-to-line">
            <xsl:with-param name="text" select="sparkle:releaseNotes"/>
        </xsl:call-template>
    </ul>
</div>


<!-- 
    XSLT1 function to split lines by * and
    create list items out of it 
-->
<xsl:template match="text/text()" name="textline-to-line">
    <xsl:param name="text" select="."/>
    <xsl:param name="separator" select="'*'"/>
    <xsl:choose>
        <xsl:when test="not(contains($text, $separator))">
            <li><xsl:value-of select="normalize-space($text)"/></li>
        </xsl:when>
        <xsl:otherwise>
            <xsl:variable name="t" select="normalize-space(substring-before($text, $separator))"/>
            <xsl:if test="not($t = '')">
            <li><xsl:value-of select="$t"/></li>
            </xsl:if>
            <xsl:call-template name="textline-to-line">
                <xsl:with-param name="text" select="substring-after($text, $separator)"/>
            </xsl:call-template>
        </xsl:otherwise>
    </xsl:choose>
</xsl:template>

Wrapping up

The earlier idea with Writing HTML into the feed wasn't so bad though. Just in case we need to write some more complex release notes, lets keep this. We just have to add an attribute type=html so the XSL parser later knows what to do:

<item>
    <sparkle:releaseNotes type="html">
    <![CDATA[
        <ul>
            <li>Added a button to change Desktop notification settings right from the prefs screen</li>
            <li>Fixed the URL to obtain the API token</li>
        </ul>
    ]]>
    </sparkle:releaseNotes>
</item>

...

<item>
    <sparkle:releaseNotes>
    <![CDATA[
        * Sparkle integration for easy updates
        * The app is now code-signed to work without warning on MacOS Lion and later
    ]]>
    </sparkle:releaseNotes>
</item>

# Efficient Sparkle Appcasts [XXX example image gingernotify left/right aligned so the text flows around.] Here at Lincoln Loop we wrote a small menu-based tool for our team discussion tool [Ginger](XXX) to indicate the arrival of new posts in the background. It's a MacOS tool and its currently in heavy development (and released ASAP). Heavy means here, that it gets an update almost every day. With that, we needed a fast and efficient update mechanism within the app, something that checks every day for updates and installs it. On MacOS there are more-or-less two ways to deploy your app this way: You use the Mac App-Store with all its (dis)advantages or you use [Sparkle](http://sparkle.andymatuschak.org/). The latter is the de-facto standard if it comes to auto-updates and deployments on the user side. And so we integrated it. ### How it works Sparkle uses a RSS feed `Appcast.xml` with some custom sugar to check for new releases, each `item` is a release, each release has a separate `sparkle:releaseNotesLink` tag which points to a `.html` file with the latest Release Notes. Thats the description you'll see in the updater window, it's a simple Webkit canvas. ``` GingerNotify Changelog https://path/to/Appcast.xml en https://path/to/v2.4 (5) Release Notes.html Mo, 10 Dez 2012 11:49:22 +0100 https://path/to/v2.4 (4) Release Notes.html Mo, 10 Dez 2012 11:49:22 +0100 ``` So, for every release there are quite a lot of actions to do: * Compile the app, sign, export and zip it * Create and write a new corresponding ReleaseNotes.html file * Add that to the "Appcast.xml" feed And so you'll end up with a lot of files. ![](sparkle1.png) ### Make it simpler The first thing you'll notice is that you don't really need a separate ReleaseNotes.html for every single release. results.title: Linux Days Chemnitz

message.body:
This weekend I've attended the Linux Days in Chemnitz. The Django Association had a booth there and I've been supporting it through the days. I'd like to share my thoughts and notes:

  • Booth support is quite fun. We didn't had so much audience, maybe 2 to 5 people per hour in average. Most of them just ate our Haribo and didnt talked in deep. I guess thats primary because it was a Linux show, not so much web focussed.

  • People there were all working for companies (read: they are no agencies) and they use Django internally, one guy even drove a embedded system cluster with Django (didn't really understand it :)

    • They don't use open source apps so much, its mostly NIH
    • They have horrible deployment setups, if at all

  • I wish more people would just stop by and say: "Hello, I'm using Django at work/personally, its awesome. Kthxbye." We'll I didn't do that either. There was a booth about Postfix and a couple of years ago I was big in the Postfix business and bought their books. I regret a little bit now to not chat with them and told that it was awesome.

  • Nobody cares about Plone either :)

  • The Django Pony is a women magnet, need to get this large one from the DjangoCon US next time

  • There is a initiative to support open source CMS's. They were at the Cebit: http://www.cmsgarden.org/

  • I had endless talks about non-Django stuff, and to be honest this was more interesting than a Django/Pycon, I learned more I can use in the upcoming days. That doesn't surprise me though.

  • Django has RequestFactory to test views without the (web) client. https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/testing/advanced/#django.test.client.RequestFactory

  • Makefiles don't suck. I only knew those auto generated Makefiles which are mostly unreadable. But they are pretty plain Bash scripts, easy to write. I'm looking how much I can use them to replace or extend Fabric. They are easier to do local tasks. I could run a Makefile via Fabric to invoke it on the remote server. Not sure yet. https://github.com/dbrgn/django-tabination/blob/master/Makefile

  • Almost forgot about Python test coverage. Though not a lot has changed https://bitbucket.org/kmike/django-coverage/src/12be8b8fe0e0?at=test_coverage

  • There is a skin to make Firefox look like Chrome, very slim and slick. https://addons.mozilla.org/de/firefox/addon/fxchrome/

  • Sublime Web inspector http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LaH_43N34Jg

There is a lot more but I need to clean my notes.

Some pics here: http://500px.com/bartTC/sets/linux_days_chemnitz_2013

message.body:
Following a discussion in IRC today, I want to make the barrier for entry as low as possible to contribute to BBMe and Ginger. I realize nobody has a lot of time to invest in these projects and it seems like when people try they get frustrated and give up. What can I do to make it as easy as possible to contribute to these? What has blocked you in the past?

A few things I've been working on or am thinking about:

  1. Local setup is fully scripted. Both can be installed by downloading and running make dependencies .
  2. Procfiles that handle running all the processes and serve as self-documentation
  3. Deploy from IRC
  4. More comprehensive test suites. Deploy with confidence
  5. Setup Jenkins to integrate with the GitHub commit status API (seems to be supported)
message.raw_body:
Following a [discussion in IRC today](https://botbot.me/private/-abMJCpTQq/msg/2287133/), I want to make the barrier for entry as low as possible to contribute to BBMe and Ginger. I realize nobody has a lot of time to invest in these projects and it seems like when people try they get frustrated and give up. What can I do to make it as easy as possible to contribute to these? What has blocked you in the past?

A few things I've been working on or am thinking about:

1. Local setup is fully scripted. Both can be installed by downloading and running `make dependencies`.
2. Procfiles that handle running all the processes and serve as self-documentation
3. Deploy from IRC
4. More comprehensive test suites. Deploy with confidence
5. Setup Jenkins to integrate with the [GitHub commit status API](https://github.com/blog/1227-commit-status-api) (seems to be [supported](https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-15045))

results.intro: Ok, If I had to summarize the common thread here ...
results.title: Turning the frown upside-down

message.body:
Ok, If I had to summarize the common thread here it would be:

  • loneliness, lack of communication
  • we're burning out because:
    • we've mastered Django and want a new set of challenges
    • the client work is boring and repetitive

Let's look at how we can work on solving these issues...
